<html><body><div><div itemprop="articleBody"><p class="mol-para-with-font">A <a target="_self" href="/news/colorado/index.html" id="mol-d7fe4040-06b4-11f1-b82c-91f0b81b9b45">Colorado</a> family say they are living in a freezing trailer with no running water after a contractor allegedly gutted their home and ran off with their life savings before finishing the job.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Nicole Chaves, 43, and her husband Mario, 44, claim they and their daughter Tillie, three, have been left virtually <a target="_self" href="/news/homelessness/index.html" id="mol-d7fc1d60-06b4-11f1-b82c-91f0b81b9b45">homeless</a>.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The couple say they paid $219,000 to contractor Daniel Parker for renovations to their three–bedroom, four–bathroom Fort Collins home last fall.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">But Parker, owner of Stonebrook Construction Group, walked off the job on January 9 allegedly leaving them with an 'unlivable shell' of a property. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The family have been staying in a fifth–wheel trailer in their backyard and say they have been forced to shower at a local gym ever since.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">A <a class="" rel="nofollow noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" href="https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-mario-nicole-rebuild-their-home">GoFundMe</a> launched by Nicole's sister–in–law, Lucia, accused Parker of having 'stole[n]' the money.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Parker strenuously denies any wrongdoing and stated that his firm carried out more work than he has been paid for.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">But the family insist they are the 'victims of a devastating construction fraud'.</p><p data-module-version="1.17.6" data-dataset-id="2255" grandma's house'.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The situation has become so dire that she will send the youngster to stay there, marking the first time the two have been apart.</p><div 'They just need a safe, dry, and heated shell so they can move inside and finish the work, one room at a time.'</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Their 1,364–square–foot home is worth around $682,000, although that valuation was made prior to the unfinished renewal.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The Chaves family also claimed that Parker failed to pay subcontractors. In turn, this allegedly leaves them facing potential liens on a currently unlivable residence.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">'Construction did not start until September, and then he abandoned the subcontractors to find out if they had been paid.'</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">The Chaves family is hoping to raise $35,000 that will go towards structural repairs and restoring their home's heat and water systems.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">As of Tuesday afternoon, about $8,500 of that goal had been achieved.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">For now, Chaves is hoping to move into even 'just one small area of the house' while the rest of the construction gets figured out.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">'If we can all live in one bedroom, at this point, that would be better than family were not 'pocketed'.</p><p class="mol-para-with-font">'Work ceased only after the homeowners materially breached the construction contract, including failure to comply with agreed payment terms for,' he claimed. </p><p class="mol-para-with-font">Parker added that he 'look[ed] forward to working with the homeowners to resolve this matter'.</p></div></div></body></html>
